aws::graph::propositions: # Piper PA 30 Twin Comanche Accident at Glacier Park International Airport
The accident involved a Piper PA 30 Twin Comanche aircraft.
The aircraft registration number was N7350Y.
The accident occurred on June 25, 2014.
The accident occurred at approximately 1700 mountain daylight time.
The accident occurred at Glacier Park International Airport in Kalispell, Montana.
The defining event of the accident was fuel starvation.
The accident involved partial loss of engine power.
The accident involved a runway excursion.
The pilot/owner was operating the airplane under Title 14 Code of Federal Regulations Part 91.
The pilot held a private pilot license.
The pilot sustained minor injuries in the accident.
The passenger sustained minor injuries in the accident.
The airplane sustained substantial damage to the right wing during the accident sequence.
The airplane sustained substantial damage to the fuselage during the accident sequence.
Visual meteorological conditions prevailed at the time of the accident.
No flight plan had been filed for the flight.
The flight was a cross-country personal flight.
The flight was originating from Glacier Park International Airport at the time of the accident.
The planned destination of the flight was Eureka, Montana.
The pilot reported the right engine did not sputter before losing power.
The pilot reported the right engine did not provide any other indications before losing power.
The airplane was airborne about 10 feet above the ground when it veered to the right.
The airplane veered away from the runway.
The pilot immediately switched fuel tanks after the engine lost power.
The pilot raised the landing gear after the engine lost power.
The pilot feathered both propellers after the engine lost power.
The airplane went into a right bank to about 80 degrees.
The pilot applied full left aileron to level the aircraft.
The pilot applied full left rudder to level the aircraft.
The pilot was able to get the airplane nearly level just prior to contacting the ground.
During the accident sequence, the right engine separated from the fuselage.
The airplane came to rest upright about 5,500 feet down the runway.
The airplane came to rest about 500 feet off to the right side of the runway.
The pilot shut the fuel valves off after the accident.
The pilot shut the fuel valves at the request of the on-scene fire personnel.
The pilot stated concern that the right fuel selector was stiff.
The pilot stated the detent on the right fuel selector was not readily apparent.
The pilot did not recall what position the fuel selectors were set to for takeoff.
A Federal Aviation Administration inspector examined the accident site.
The Federal Aviation Administration inspector observed no fuel leaking from the airplane.
The Federal Aviation Administration inspector stated the main tanks appeared to be dry.
The Federal Aviation Administration inspector stated the auxiliary tanks were almost full.

text:
# Factual Information

## History of Flight

| Takeoff | Fuel starvation (Defining event) |
| Takeoff | Loss of engine power (partial) |
| Takeoff | Runway excursion |

On June 25, 2014, about 1700 mountain daylight time, a Piper PA 30 Twin Comanche, N7350Y, collided with terrain following a loss of engine power on the right engine during takeoff from Glacier Park International Airport, Kalispell, Montana. The pilot/owner was operating the airplane under the provisions of Title 14 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 91. The private pilot and passenger sustained minor injuries. The airplane sustained substantial damage to the right wing and fuselage during the accident sequence. Visual meteorological conditions prevailed, and no flight plan had been filed. The cross-country personal flight was originating at the time with a planned destination of Eureka, Montana.

The pilot reported that the right engine did not sputter or provide any other indications before losing power. The airplane was airborne about 10 feet above the ground when it veered to the right, away from the runway. The pilot immediately switched fuel tanks, raised the gear, and feathered both propellers. The airplane went into a right bank to about 80 degrees, and the pilot was able to get the airplane nearly level, applying full left aileron and rudder, just prior to contacting the ground. During the accident sequence, the right engine separated from the fuselage.

The airplane came to rest upright about 5,500 feet down the runway and 500 feet off to the right side of the runway.

The pilot stated that he shut the fuel valves off after the accident, at the request of the on-scene fire personnel. The pilot stated concern that the right fuel selector was stiff, and the detent was not readily apparent. He did not recall what position the fuel selectors were set to for takeoff.

Examination of the accident site was conducted by a Federal Aviation Administration inspector and revealed that the airplane's fuselage and wings sustained substantial damage. The inspector observed no fuel leaking from the airplane. He stated upon inspection, the main tanks appeared to be dry and the axillary tanks were almost full.
